vehicles.name: Steam Tank
vehicles.desc: Riveted iron plate, a coal-fired boiler, and the shuddering determination of Victorian engineering applied to warfare. She advances through mud and wire at walking pace, trailing steam, and her crew works in temperatures that would kill an unprotected man in an hour.
vehicles.notes: The Victorian steam tank variant emphasises the engineering challenge. Track coal and water as resources. The engineer maintains boiler pressure while the gunner fires and the commander navigates. Three crew roles, three players, constant resource management.

vehicles.name: Clockwork Spider
vehicles.desc: A masterwork of precision engineering — eight legs moving in perfect synchronised rhythm, each joint hand-fitted by a master clockmaker. She's a military contract worth a fortune, and losing one in combat means the Treasury wants to know why.
vehicles.notes: This clockwork spider variant emphasises cost and rarity. She's irreplaceable in the field — there's no factory to produce spares. Damage to her mechanisms requires a skilled clockmaker, not a blacksmith. Use her as the special asset the military can't afford to lose.

vehicles.name: Ornithopter
vehicles.desc: Experimental flying machine with mechanical wings. She's been through six prototypes and four test pilots. The current version mostly works. The word 'mostly' keeps her designer awake at night.
vehicles.notes: The Victorian ornithopter is experimental and dangerous. She pushes Piloting difficulties up by one step compared to conventional aircraft. Critical Failures have dramatic consequences. Use her for inventor-character campaigns where the vehicle is as much a character as the pilot.

vehicles.name: Steam Carriage
vehicles.desc: The horseless carriage that scandalises society and excites engineers in equal measure. She burns coal, she scares horses, and she represents the future — if the future can solve the problem of the boiler occasionally exploding.
vehicles.notes: The Victorian steam carriage is your urban transport. She's a conversation piece, a status symbol, and a chase vehicle through gaslit streets. Her top speed is modest but in the 1870s she's the fastest personal vehicle available.

vehicles.name: Ironclad Monitor
vehicles.desc: Low in the water, armoured against everything afloat, and carrying a single turret with guns that can demolish a wooden ship of the line in a single broadside. She's the future of naval warfare and every admiral who grew up under sail hates her.
vehicles.notes: The ironclad represents the end of the sailing navy. Use her for Victorian naval campaigns where the old order confronts the industrial revolution. She's slow, she handles poorly in heavy seas, but nothing wooden survives her guns.

vehicles.name: Zeppelin (Victorian)
vehicles.desc: A rigid airship the length of a cricket pitch, carrying passengers in luxury and cargo in bulk above the weather that plagues surface transport. She's the ocean liner of the sky — slow, stately, and representing the triumph of lighter-than-air engineering.
vehicles.notes: The Victorian zeppelin is your aerial transport and adventure platform. She carries enough passengers for a mystery scenario — murder on the airship at ten thousand feet. She's also vulnerable to weather, fire, and anyone willing to shoot at a hydrogen-filled envelope.

vehicles.name: Submarine (Nautilus)
vehicles.desc: A Victorian submarine powered by engines that shouldn't work and navigating by instruments that barely do. She sinks when intended, surfaces when possible, and her crew breathe air that tastes of oil and desperation. She's the cutting edge and she knows it.
vehicles.notes: The Victorian submarine is your adventure vehicle for exploration campaigns. She reaches underwater locations — shipwrecks, sea caves, lost cities — that nothing else can. Her limitations create natural tension: limited air, limited power, and the ocean trying to crush her hull.

vehicles.name: Walking Fortress
vehicles.desc: A three-storey structure on mechanical legs, carrying artillery, a garrison, and the flag of whatever empire was wealthy and insane enough to build her. She strides across colonial landscapes inspiring awe and terror in equal measure.
vehicles.notes: The Victorian walking fortress is your colonial-era superweapon. She's deployed against 'lesser' civilisations — which creates morally complex scenarios about imperial power and its consequences. She's nearly unstoppable with period weapons.

vehicles.name: Armoured Train
vehicles.desc: The pride of the railway companies and the terror of anyone who lives near the tracks. She carries troops, guns, and supplies along rail lines that span continents. She's the backbone of colonial logistics and the first target of any insurgency.
vehicles.notes: The Victorian armoured train is your rail campaign vehicle. She connects frontier outposts, delivers reinforcements, and attracts every bandit and revolutionary within earshot of her whistle. Rail ambushes are the classic encounter.

vehicles.name: Difference Engine Walker
vehicles.desc: A mechanical soldier the size of a house, guided by a computing engine that processes punch cards fed by a sweating operator. She follows orders with mechanical precision and absolutely no imagination. She's the empire's answer to problems that require more firepower than diplomacy.
vehicles.notes: The Victorian difference engine walker is your proto-robot. She's powerful but literal — she follows her programmed instructions exactly, which means clever enemies exploit her predictable behaviour. Reprogramming her punch cards mid-battle is the engineer's crisis moment.
